text:
I've tried a few Spinach and Artichoke dips from this site and I've loved them all but this is BY FAR my favorite! It is just perfect, and delicious! I used Sour Cream instead of mayo and it was PERFECT!! YUM!!! I used 2 cloves of garlic, did without the basil. I also used Whipped Cream Cheese, it is so much easier to work with. I mixed the shredded cheese into the mixture, much better that way than on top! I thought it got yucky if you put it on top. A hard layer and impossible to dip in. I serve with tortilla chips and baguette. I even mix it all together the day before and put it in a pan in the fridge and then when I'm ready to bake it I throw it in the oven! I make this and bring it whenever I'm going to someone's house and EVERYONE loves it. I can't even tell you how many times I've been asked for this recipe, EVERY time I make it! LOVE IT!

country:
None
text:
This is another fabulous version of the spinach/artichoke dip.  However, I used sour cream instead of mayonnaise - much better! We use a bag of frozen spinach (rather than the boxes or fresh) and just squeeze it dry - the spinach quality is better.  You can really add a little of whatever you'd like, and it is ALL good! I added chives to add some more green to it. I also have added a few dashes of Frank's hot sauce (which does not overwhelm the other flavors - just enchances them!). You can toss in bacon bits, chopped garlic, chopped red peppers (not green - ew!), etc. Be sure to really chop up the spinach and artichokes - no big chunks for this dip please.  You could toss in regular onions too, but I think it is great without them.  It does take a little longer to bake with the sour cream - and I use a 9x13 glass pan, so you can see the edges getting golden!  I buttered the edges of the pan last tmie - OGM - the dip was gone in under two hours!  This is a keeper, and has been a request since we first made it . YUM!!!!  (We use Ritz crackers,but this is good on Ritz, tortilla chips - almost anything!)  If you have any left over, it is just as good warmed up in the microwave the next day.  (I think we've had leftovers ONCE!)  Rich, so you don't want to eat it all the time, but if you want a great dip - go for the best!  (No cartons of liquidly sour cream junk when this is so easy to make!)

text:
LOVE IT! I used light cream cheese (16oz instead of just 8oz), jarred minced garlic instead of wasting my time mincing it myself and I used more spinach than called for to ensure this was actual spinach dip and not just a cream cheese dip (I posted a picture). I also mixed the mozzarella in with everything else instead of just putting it on the top. I paired this with the "Pita Chips" recipe on this site submitted by Dawn. The two are match made in heaven! I cannot speak highly enough about this recipe. Thanks a bunch!

This is the best Artichoke and Spinach Dip in the world! Once we discovered how great the recipe was, I made it two more times that week! My mother came over and we made double the amount and ate it with water crackers while drinking pina coladas and playing scrabble. We hardly played at all, though. We couldn't stop eating that dip! I think this is a fantastic recipe, but for our tastes I added a tsp. of cayenne pepper and a little more garlic. Wonderful dip!

text:
I love artichokes and cheese, but hate spinach. I have to admit, I could not stop eating this dip. I made it for a New Year's party and thank goodness I doubled the recipe. I served it with parmesan-garlic toast rounds and Triscut crackers. It was a H-I-T. A bit on the expensive side, but well worth it when the compliments start pouring in. One hint: Mix most of the mozarella into the dip, and sprinkle just enough on the top to brown and present nicely. This makes the taste great, and when it cools you have no hard layer to fight with to get to the dip.

I fixed this as an appetizer for our Labor Day cookout and it was amazingly good. One of my teenagers, that hasn't eaten anything green in years, was actually eating the bread bowl when the dip was finished. I did take other reviewers advice and made a few changes: substitute sour cream for mayo, increase garlic to 3 cloves, mix mozzarella in before baking, and serve in a bread bowl. Everyone just raved about this dip and it disappeared quicK!

text:
Omigod this is FANTASTIC!  I've made it over 5 times, and every single time the serving bowl is wiped clean!  You'll need about 3 baguettes per recipe, sliced about 1" thick, if that's how you want to serve it.  I also normally make double batches since the package of frozen spinach at the store is enough for 2 recipes (I hate to waste it), and always add a little more of the cheese, spices, & garlic.  Also, if you use the artichoke hearts from Costco, they have an irresistable flavor and are marinated in olive oil & herbs (which helps enhance the flavor of the dip)--plus, you can steal pieces and still have enough in the jar for your recipe!  Just FYI, a double batch fits perfectly in a 9x9 pyrex dish, so you can just bake it, throw the plastic lid on & it's easy to transport to your next party!

text:
I know.. I know.. everyone complains when we modify recipes, but this one definitely deserved something more - but not much.  I put a large clove of garlic, and drained artichokes in a food processor and pulsed a few times to break up.  Then I added the drained spinach.  I removed the mix from the processor and set aside in a bowl and added the cream cheese, parmigianna reggiano and about 1/2 cup of the mozzerella.  I gave that a nice couple of pulses to mix and then threw the artichoke mix back in - this time with a short squeeze of a half lemon and some salt and pepper.  I left out the basil thinking it seemed odd to be in there.  I topped the dish with 1/2 cup finely shredded mozzerella and baked for 25 minutes at 375.  It was absolute heaven.. total perfection.  My guys and family ate it like there was no tomorrow.  This recipe is definitely the best I've ever had.  Thank you for sharing!!

text:
This dip is AWESOME. I've made it a few times now, and it always gets rave reviews. It's creamy and flavorful and just really delicious. I only make a few changes - I, like a bunch of other people have said, use sour cream instead of mayo, and I use twice the amount of spinach and of garlic. I also stir mozzerella cheese right into the dip before baking, as well as sprinking it on top. I've served it with pita chips and with crackers, but I think it's best with tortilla chips. Thank you Tiffany for the great recipe! This is one of my favorite things to make for parties.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time making a spinach artichoke dip and it was awesome! Brought as an appetizer to Thanksgiving and served with cubes of french bread I tossed in a touch of olive oil & seasonings plus triscuits and tortilla chips. Everyone raved about it, I doubled the recipe, and it still went too fast. I knew that it was a real winner when my roommate's grandmother asked for the recipe!

Taking the suggestion of other reviewers, I made a few changes. I used 2 cloves of garlic instead of one, I added 1/3 cup diced onion, a few pinches of Cayenne and used fresh spinach instead of frozen. Also, I used half mayo and half sour cream, using a little more of these than the recipe called for. I sauteed spinach, garlic, and onion in olive oil first, then mixed in with everything else. I thought the mixture was a little too thick and wanted it to turn out really creamy, so before I transferred to the baking dish I stirred in some milk (maybe a 1/3 a cup).

This was a huge hit, I will make it again soon. Next time, I will probably increase the spinach a bit and add more whole milk hoping it turns out just a little less thick. Also I will be baking this in the dutch oven, or a bakeable crock pot dish. You definitely want to bake to brown the cheese on top, but I feel you need to keep it hot for serving too. If you are browsing for a great, hearty appetizer this is definitely worth a try!

text:
I made this dish not even knowing what an artichoke was!!!  Took it to a get together with friends tonight and it went over great (I think my hubby ate the most!). Made a few alterations as follows:  used 1/4 cup sour cream and a 1/4 mayo.  Found an Italian blend of shredded cheeses at Safeway (Lucerne brand) which included mozza, parmesan, provolone and fontina and just used 3/4 cups of this and mixed/stirred it into the rest.  Baked it for about 1/2 when it started to bubble, took it out an sprinkled some more of the cheese blend on top and broiled for about 6/7 minutes until it got lightly browned.  Will definitely be making again.  Thanks so much!!!

text:
Absolutely the most amazing, phenomenal spinach-artichoke dip on planet earth. I'm getting ready to make it for the Super Bowl because EVERY party we go to this is the #1 request. Like others we use sour cream instead of mayo. When you make the dip, before baking, it is pretty thick. But as it bakes all the cheeses just melt together and you are left with a creamy concoction of gooey goodness. I plan on posting this recipe to my blog  to spread the love! I urge you to try this recipe. You will NOT regret it.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous recipe without any changes (five stars worth!), and even better once you start tailoring it to your own tastes.  I rarely measure the cheese so don't be worried if you have to fudge it a bit, and have substituted havarti for the romano twice now.  It gives it a creamier consistency and a more mellow flavor.  I usually double the artichokes and have added variation such as roasted red peppers, bacon, sauteed garlic and onions, 1/2 sour cream 1/2 mayo, canned crab meat, salad shrimp, clams, olives, scallions on top...mmm.  My favorite chip to serve with it are the Simply Naked Pita Chips from costco.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fabulous!!  I am actually dieting right now and I was looking for some healthier options for appetizers.  I made this recipe with reduced fat cream cheese and instead of the mayo I used Fat Free Sour cream.  I omitted the layer of mozzarella cheese on the top and just stirred in about 1/8 of a cup of it.  I also decreased the rest of the cheese by a little bit and increased the spinach a little bit.  I made sure that I drained the spinach REALLY well, I think that if you didn't the dip wouldn't have as creamy of a texture.  I also added an extra clove of garlic.  I served this with a chunks of french bread, crackers, and pretzels and it was wonderful!!  I had several people tell me this was the best spinach artichoke dip they have ever had, everyone asked me for the recipe, and no one could believe that it was low-fat and low-calorie.  This is definitely going to become a regular when I entertain.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this for a dinner party tonight, and everyone absolutely loved it! The only things I did differently were that I stirred in the mozzarella cheese rather than top the dip with it and I used a little less artichokes than what the recipe calls for, as a whole can seemed to be a bit too much. I also added a little more garlic than what the recipe calls for (and I'm glad I did). The dip was a little too thick (but still very good), so the next time I make it, I might add a little more mayonnaise or a splash of milk (?). Also - I found that the romano cheese really added great flavor. I think it may have been a bit bland without it. I also used whipped cream cheese, which made the mixture much easier to stir. I will most definitely make this again!

text:
This dip is so friggin good :) We had a pot luck last nite with WAYYYY too much food so as we were sending food home with people they were fighting over who got to take the last of the dip home! 

I put the dip together in the morning and just kept it in the fridge. About a half hr before I assumed people would show up, I popped it in the oven . But, as always, most were late so I just kept it in the oven with the oven turned off and once people began to arrive i just turned on the broiler for about 5-10 mins. Perfect!!! Definately keeping this recipe! Oh, and the only thing I changed was using 1/2 c of parmesean instead of 1/4 c of parm and 1/4 c of romano.

I've been making this recipe for about 2 years now (since I found it)! It's amazing exactly as written. The one thing that I was unsure of when I first started making it was the kind of artichokes. This is the key to this recipe! I have tried it with the artichokes in the plain water and the artichokes flavored in the oil with seasoning. It's amazing with the flavored artichokes and not so with them in just water. I'm making it again in a few days and I always get rave reviews! Enjoy!!

text:
I love this recipe!!! I have taken it to work and to holiday family parties. This is always requested over and over! The only thing I do, adding to it, is instead of just adding Parmesan and Romano separately I buy the cheese blend of Parmesan, Romano, and Asagio mixed blend. It makes it easier and the Asagio cheese gives it a smoky flavor. I do add one extra clove of garlic and use garlic powder instead. I also use fresh basil instead of dried. Lastly, I let this mixture sit in the fridge overnight! This is key to really lock in all of the flavor. It is soooo good!

text:
Great recipe. I used low fat cheeses and it still turned out well. I also took other people's suggestions and did this: added two green onions, a dash of Tobasco, 1/2 lemon juice, and used 3 cloves of garlic, mixed the mozerella into the dip and sprinkled the top with a little more mozerella and parmesan. Did not use romano cheese. I'd definitely make it again. I rate the recipe as is with 4 stars but if you modify it to your own taste (like I did), it's a 5.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making my own stock version of  hot spinach and artichoke dip over the last ten years and decided to try something new! I am so glad I did! This was fantastic! I think it's the blend of different cheeses that makes it so tasty. I cheated, I used the "Italian Cheese" which is a blend of 6 cheeses, Asiago, Parmesan, Romano, Fontina, low moisture Mozzarella and Provalone. It made it so much easier to make and added the different shades of flavors to the dip. I also mixed in the regular Mozzarella and on a whim, added a little extra to the top for appearance. I added an extra clove of garlic because I am all about garlic. I was a little leary of the basil but it added a nice flavor to it! Throw out your usual recipe for today and try this one, you will not be sorry!

text:
I've never had so many raves on a dish that's this easy to make.  I used a blender to chop the artichokes and it took all of 5 seconds.  For the grated cheese, I found a blend of Parm, Romano, and Asiago that I used and worked great.  I accidentally tripled the garlic and I was afraid I over did it until I tasted it and realized it was going to work out, so definitely add more garlic and skip the garlic salt.  I used mayo, but will try sour cream next time as others have suggested to taste the difference.  One final note, I used light cream cheese and light mayo and thought the result was fantastic.

text:
Though another glowing review of this wonderful recipe really isn't necessary, I will offer my modifications. I use reduced fat mayo, and use 50/50 regular and light cream cheese. I find it a bit thick and so I add a half cup of 1% milk. I also double the amount of chopped (frozen and thawed but not drained)spinach. Not squeezing the water out adds additional needed moisture, and reduces prep time and mess. I do splurge though, and use monterey jack cheese, which I mix throughout. I don't add additional salt, since the parm and romano add all the salt needed.  I also double (at least) the garlic, and add a pinch of cheyenne. I make this for every holiday, and it is scrumptious!

userID:
102238
Display Name:
Impish
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Throw out all your other artichoke/spinach dip recipes.  This recipe is absolute perfection -- must be the cream cheese, it's the only spinach artichoke dip recipe on this site that uses it rather than sour cream. Very rich, cheesy,  luscious and a nice mellow tang from the artichokes, this one is a heavyweight and needs a substantial cracker or firm sourdough to pile it on.


Like many other posters recommended, I mixed the mozzarella in rather than plop it on top. I also mixed in 2 TBS of sour cream just to give it slightly better stirability (don't ruin it with tons of sour cream--honestly, nearly all recipes on the site call for sour cream as a major ingredient and once you have a cream cheese-ruled dip like this you won't wanna go back to bland ol' sour cream!)


I'm done searching for the magic disappearing dip -- I've found it. My only suggestion -- if you have more than six people or so, DOUBLE THE RECIPE. We had seven guests and this dip was inhaled in minutes.  Gone. Wild! We made it several hours before a party and put it in fridge, covered, so the ingredients (esp. garlic) could really blend and fuse. The pre-packaged romano and parmesan blends in most grocery stores make this extremely easy to make!

userID:
3402949
Display Name:
ENL1976
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had a dinner party last night and this was a great hit! I used whipped cream cheese in a tub instead of a cheese block. I used 1/8c mayo + 1/8c sour cream vs all mayo...the mix of the two made it creamier but not quite creamy enough...next time I will try doing the 1/4c of mayo and 1/8c sour cream...definitely use both though. I bought the bagged shredded parm/romano cheese mix vs separate cheeses. I added extra garlic...about 2-3 cloves total (used the minced jar kind) as I LOVE garlic and used the 1/4 tsp garlic salt. I used a 10oz frozen spinach package and was not too much spinach...be sure it is dry though...if you want more artichoke taste just cut it down a bit. Also did a pinch of cayenne...could have added a little more. I cooked it in a brownie size pyrex dish and then transferred it to a serving bowl and served it with tortilla chips. (As someone mentioned earlier, it is better to bake it in a shallow type pan vs a bowl...it seemed to cook better). Next time I will try adding scallions and lemon juice as others have done....but even without these last two ingredients this dish was awesome! Oh, I almost forgot...put all of the ingredients in a food processor (I used my mini-chopper) after all together...this really marinates the flavors and makes it nice and chopped. Also, I made it the night before and then took it out of the fridge about an hour before baking. Fantastic!

text:
This was just okay.  I added a little extra mozzarella (I like a very cheesey dip) and an 1/8 tsp. cayenne for a little heat.  I was not pleased with the consistency of this dip.  I was hoping for something a lot creamier.  I had 3 dips out at the same time, and although people said they liked this one, it did not go.  The next day I doctored it up with 1/4 C. sour cream and 1 C. monterey jack cheese, reheated it, and it tasted better and had the creaminess I was looking for, but I still ended up throwing almost the entire thing away.  I'm very glad I didn't double it.

text:
This was a easy and delicious recipe!  I had two parties to attend and I made this both times, and everyone raved. I substituted the mayo with sour cream and I bought an Italian 4 cheese fresh shredded mixture, containing romano, parmesean, asiago and provolone cheeses. I mixed the cheese mixture with the cream cheese, sour cream, minced garlic and basil. I gently stirred in the spinach and artichokes and then sprinkled more of the cheese mix on top for baking.  I already have requests to bring it as an appetizer for our family Christmas Eve party.  Thank you for the great recipe!

city:

country:
None
text:
This recipe was ok, but as with many others, I found it dry and difficult to scoop with tortilla chips. The mayo made it too tangy with a weird after taste and dominated much of the flavor. I took away the mayo, added about 4 oz of goat cheese, a couple dashes of crushed red pepper, 2 more garlic cloves, a dash of Worcestershire sauce and another 1/4 c of Parmesan cheese and the consistency and taste improved quite a bit. I also add about a cup and a half of spinach because I like a thicker, more veggie-filled dip. I'll use this as a base recipe again, but with my own modifications.

text:
I've been searching for a great spinach/artichoke dip, and finally found a winner! I made a few moderations to mine. I used two cloves of garlic instead of one, by mistake.(my 12 year old daughter was reading me the recipe from upstairs.. not sure what happened!) I also added 1/4 cup of sour cream to it.. I was serving it the next day, and was afraid it would go dry. The next day, after sitting in the fridge all day, and having already been previously baked the day before.. it needed a bit of milk.. I added just enough to moisten it, threw it in my mother in laws warming oven.. and it was scrumptious.. This is coming from a family of picky eaters.. Everyone hovered over the dip, served in a french round loaf, until it was scraped clean off the bread! My little nephew ate it instead of his Thanksgiving dinner. Thanks for the wonderful recipe! As far as using two cloves of garlic instead of one, take caution if anyone does that like myself.. It would definitely be for garlic lovers only!

text:
This was awesome! I took the advice of others and actually mixed in the mozzarella cheese instead of putting it on top. Also, when I first took it out of the oven, I noticed it had a little bit of a runny consistency (although still very good!), so I let it cool down for a little bit, and put it back in the oven for about 10-15 more minutes, which made it really thick and extremely delicious!!!  It tastes just like, or better, than the hot artichoke spinach dip from Olive GardeN!

text:
This dip is delicious. I sauteed fresh spinach in butter and garlic, adding the artichoke hearts as the spinach was wilting. I also used sour cream instead of mayonnaise, and swiss cheese instead of romano. I followed the advice of another comment and mixed half the mozzarella into the mixture before putting it in the baking dish, and then sprinkling the rest on top with a little bit of grated asiago. I served it with tortilla chips and with slices of toasted ciabatta (brushed with garlic olive oil before baking at 350 F for 10 minutes), and it was gone very quickly. Thank you for sharing such a fabulous recipe! :)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe as written.  However, as you adapt it to your own tastes, some suggestions that I have are to 1) not be afraid of fresh garlic!  I use FAR more than a clove (more like half a head or more, depending on the size of the head) b/c I LOVE garlic and it makes this dish divine.  Also, I like to mix in a handful of the powder Parmesan for flavor along with shredded (and cheese is good).  I prefer the spinach and artichokes to be chopped small rather than roughly chopped (I use my food processor for this, as well as to chop the garlic).  Make sure they are very dry!  A ricer works well, or your hands to squeeze out the liquid before chopping.  I use half of a box 10 oz box of frozen spinach and that's the perfect amount.  Add a dash of red pepper flakes if you like it spicy.  Top it with some diced tomatoes, serve on garlic bread and you have a delicious meal.

userID:
7209268
Display Name:
Megamuffin
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/657521.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh how I loooove spinach artichoke dip and this is the only recipe I use to make it! I haven't even tried any other recipes because I like this one so well. However, I gave it 4 stars because I think it needs a little "finesse" to really come out super. Some reviewers complained of a "fishy" or weird taste - this is probably from the spinach. Frozen boxed spinach can have a weird fishy taste. Try frozen in a bag or fresh. Many found the dip too thick - and indeed it does come out thick if prepared as written. I add a lot more creamy white stuff, usually some combination of plain yogurt and sour cream with just a few squirts of mayo - to total up to a cup. You could also reduce the cream cheese if its still too thick. Also more cheese - and mix the mozzarella in instead of sprinkling on top. Given these additions, I also use a good bit more spinach and always the full can of artichokes, both diced up quite fine. Always turns out delicious and even the leftovers heat up well.

text:
This was a big hit when I made it for friends and family. I also used sour cream instead of mayonnaise to make it a little less greasy. I mixed the mozzarella cheese into the mixture and topped with some shredded Asiago cheese. Instead of putting the dip into one baking dish I used mini pie tins so everyone had there own individual dish.
I lightly buttered some pita bread and then fried them gently until golden brown and crisp. I cut the pita into triangle wedges and placed onto a serving platter and watched it all disappear! Everyone will be asking you for this recipe :)

I brought this to Thanksgiving dinner and everyone loved it!  Many people asked for the recipe.  I made a few changes.  I used sour cream instead of mayo, an entire box of frozen spinach (just over 1 cup), 2 t of minced garlic instead of garlic salt, and mixed the mozzarella in with all the other cheeses instead of sprinkling it on top.  I will make this again!

text:
I followed some of the changes that were listed--I used sour cream instead of mayo (texture was great), used 3-4 cloves of garlic, used only grated paremesan cheese (all I had on hand) and used shredded swiss cheese instead of the mozzarella.  I also mixed the swiss in the dip as well as on the top---it was great.   I mixed this the night before and stuck it in the fridge--then when I needed it, I popped it in the microwave for a couple minutes---perfect!!!!!  Next time I will make a double batch as I only got two bites---the dip went extremely fast!!!  My boys loved it!  Highly recommended.

This recipe worked very well for me and it's super delicious! The best thing I loved about this recipe is how flexible you can be with the measurements, no measuring cups required =) Also I just realized that I used dried oregano instead of basil, but it still tasted great! I think one full can of artichoke is too much, so I used half the can approx. 3 hearts. I also tried this dip with pita chips (stacys twice baked pita chips), and again it was pure deliciousness. Good for any occasion! Plus, you can mix everything a day ahead, and bake when ready. I LOVE THIS DIP!!!!

This is a fantstic recipe. The only thing I did differently is I used real artichokes instead of canned. The artichoke itself was so rich and really added to the dip. Yummmm, I will defnitely be making this one again!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This was a good dip, but definitely needs to be served in a crockpot to keep it warm.  I simply placed the casserole on the table straight out of the oven.  It was good then.  But as the night and dip wore on, it became inedible.  I would try it again, but I will be sure to keep it warm.  As for changes, I 1) used sour cream instead of mayo, 2) 1 cup fresh spinach instead of frozen, 3) about 4 cloves of roasted garlic and 4) 1/2 cup of parmesan instead of the parm/romano mix and 5) mixed most of the mozzarella in with the dip and only sprinkled a little bit on top.

I made this the day before I planned to serve it as an appetizer on Easter Sunday and put it in the fridge. text:
I started making this dip a couple of years ago and taking it to parties for an appetizer.  Everywhere I have taken it, I have gotten many rave reviews and people asking for the recipe.  I have even been asked to bring it again (but to double the recipe next time).

Quick tip that I do: I use fat free cream cheese and mayonaise instead of the full fat stuff.  Also, I get low fat tortilla chips and low fat cheeses if I can find it.  You would think that would change the flavor...but it still gets great reviews.  When I tell the girls that it's calorie friendly, they all love it even more!!!  It's worth trying and healthier.

What a hit!! I made this as one of my New Years Eve appitizers and it was great! I just have one small time and money saving tip! Where it asks for 1/3 cup of each Romano and Parmesan cheese, I actually use 2/3 cups of Kraft Shredded Parmesan, Romano and Asiago Natural Cheese (in the canister)! It saved time and $!! What an excellent recipe!! Im adding it to my recipe box for sure!! Check out my recipe for Eazy Breezy Chicken Cheezy Dip for your next party or get together!! YUM!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a great appetizer.  I served it at a recent Christmas party for colleagues and it was the first thing to disappear amidst raves and requests for the recipe!  I did do a few things differently because I couldn't find everything in Poland, where I'm currently living: I used only parmesan cheese (3/4 cup fresh shredded), I replaced the mayonnaise with sour cream (12%) as recommended by some other reviews, I used fresh spinach that I chopped and put directly in the dip instead of frozen, and I used a standard sized package of fresh mozzarella which I chopped into very small blocks and mixed in with the dip instead of on top (I was surprised that it didn't make the dip too watery, either) and I omitted the basil.  I served it with tortilla chips and toasted baguette, although the tortilla chips seemed more popular.  It was very good, even with all my changes!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a girls get together--went over well.  Four stars as I modified the recipe based on other's advice.  Used sour cream instead of mayo, used fresh moz. instead of shredded, used all parm, no romano; used three cloves of garlic, no garlic salt, no additional salt (enough salt in the artichoke hearts and cheeses).  Also, I softened the hunks of moz w/the cream cheese by placing in a metal bowl and setting in warm water for a few minutes.  It turned out great--people definitely ask for the recipe on this one!  This is a very thick dip--tortilla chips do not stand a chance.  I served with a spoon and had some toasted cocktail breads and pita chips to serve with it.

text:
Exactly what I was looking for (with a few changes suggested by other reviewers). I doubled the recipe for 12 people and it was just the right amount. Doubled, I increased the spinach to 16 oz, added 1/2 cup of sour cream, added 1 tablespoon of lemon juice, added 8 oz of sliced water chestnuts (chopped), added one small onion (chopped) and split the mozzarella up - mixing half into the mixture and leaving half on top. Excellent!

Display Name:
tigerlily-
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! I made a few alterations, mostly just using fresh ingredients instead of frozen (fresh mozzarella, spinach,--make sure to pat this try after cooking!--and garlic cloves), but used a jar of artichoke hearts and it tasted just fine. I subbed sour cream for mayonnaise as other comments suggested, and used about half a cup of grated Parmigiano-Reggiano, as I didn't have any Romano. Make sure to mix in the mozzarella with other ingredients, and grate some parmesan on top to give you a nice golden-brown crust.

Mine ended up a bit on the dry side, probably because I let it bake for too long, but it was very very good and great as a leftover!

text:
This dip was amazing! I only had about 4-6oz of cream cheese, so I just made up the difference with sour cream. And although I love basil, I didn't have any today and I didn't find that I missed it at all. Plus, there's enough mayo in it that you can skip greasing the pan. 
In short, this dip is creamy and cheesy without being too thick or too runny. Just perfect!

This dip is FABULOUS!!!  I made it for a dinner party I was hosting and the guests couldn't stop raving about it. Its truly an awesome dip and definitely an appetizer staple from now on.  I followed the advice of others and used sour cream instead of mayo, put the mozzarella in the mixture instead of on top, and doubled the garlic. UPDATE: I have made this at every party Ive hosted & pot lucks attended and its ALWAYS gotten rave reviews.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this recipe all the time and love it! It's always a hit. I have made some changes, though which make it suit my taste a bit more. I always use fresh spinach, not frozen, and two cloves of garlic. I use low-fat cream cheese and sour cream (in place of mayonnaise), and don't use basil or garlic salt--sometimes a dash of garlic powder, or a few dashes of crushed red pepper. Additionally, to make prep a lot quicker I just use a reduced fat italian cheese blend rather than all of the individual cheeses--1/2C or so in the mix and another 1/4 on top. Turns out great EVERY TIME--this is a very forgiving recipe!

text:
I've made this dip many times now, and it usually ends up being the star of the show because everyone gathers around the dip saying that they can't stop eating it. 

I substitute light sour cream for the mayonnaise and also light cream cheese (can't tell the difference). What really makes this dip incredible is if you use FRESH mozzarella cut into small cubes and mixed into the dip for baking so that you get small chunks of melted cheese as you dip. I also add extra garlic and extra herbs (italian seasoning works fine). 

Soooo good. It gets completely devoured every time!

text:
Very yummy! I made some slight modifications on this recipe.  I substituted sour cream for the mayo, omitted the basil and garlic powder and doubled the spinach and mozzarella.  Then, after reading some negative reviews that said it was "too thick" I added a few tablespoons of heavy cream to ensure it was nice and creamy.  Tossed it all in a loaf pan and baked for a half hour.  It was superb.  I served it with tortilla chips and crispy baguette slices. Would highly recommend serving for a party.  I will definitely be making this again! :)

THIS is it!! My husband and I sometimes enjoy spinach and artichoke dip at different restaurants when we go on our dates. Even though I've made it several times at home, it never tasted as good or creamy as the ones in the restaurants. This recipe changed that! This one is as good as any we've had! It is going directly into my favorite recipes and I will be making it more often! I followed the recipe ingredients but used my own homemade mayo from this site, stirred in the mozzarella as someone suggested and bought fresh spinach so I cooked it before adding it to the dip. I mixed everything with my hand mixer and then transferred to my mini slow cooker dip crock which warmed it and kept it warm for our New Years eve guests. Sooooo yummy! I'd give it more stars if I could! Thanks Tiffany!

text:
This is AMAZING dip! It was all gone within 30 minutes. However, I changed up the original recipe a little bit. I first put the artichoke hearts, spinach and a 1/2 teaspoon of minced garlic into the blender and blended it until it was blended but not completely ground. Then I mixed all the ingredients into a bowl. BUT, I added extra cheese and a little asiago cheese, I also added 2 tsp of minced garlic and 1/4 cup of half & half, mixed in most of the mozzarella in with the dip and it turned out incredible. I will continue to make this recipe, it's SO GOOD! P.S (also didn't use mayo, sub sour cream)

text:
Look no further for a spinach and artichoke dip recipe. This. Is. Phenomenal. It tastes like something you would get at a restaurant, only better. The only changes I have ever made were to add more garlic (my husband and I are big garlic fans), and to mix the mozzarella in instead of putting it on top (so it doesn't make those unsightly cheese puddles at the top after baking).

It's this good: the last time I took it to a party, though it's always a hit, people liked it so much that the host's food was ignored until my dish was completely clean of any dip. The only problem? You'll never have any leftovers for yourself!

This was so great! I always order this at restaurants and now I can make it at home whenever I want! My family loved it and it was gone in less than 30 minutes. Next time I will definately double the recipe. The only thing that I changed was that I put more garlic (we love garlic) and I wasn't able to use garlic salt because I didn't have any so I just used garlic powder and a little extra salt. Also, wasn't able to find Romana cheese so I just bought the Italian blend cheese which had it in it. I also mixed the mozzarella in with the dip and just sprinkled the good Parmesan on top before baking. This was awesome and I will be making this again! Thanks for the recipe!

I made this for a gathering and everyone loved it! I did add a clove of real garlic rather than garlic salt and I replaced the mayo with sour cream like others suggested. I will admit I was a little disappointed with the lack of creaminess, as I thought it would be more creamy. I'm thinking that's because I used sour cream rather than mayo. Also, I didn't have the separate cheeses listed so I used an Italian Cheese blend which had both the parm and romano cheesed in it. It was a great, fairly easy recipe to make and I'll definitely be making it again!

Can I say that this recipe made me look like a master chef to my friends!! I love this dip when we eat out, but had never tried making it at home. I made this last night to serve along with the demonstrators dishes for a Pampered Chef party. Awesome! The only way I could find romano cheese at two stores was in a fresh grated mix with parmesan cheese (not the green can) so I went with that. Thanks for making me look so competent to my friends!!

Five Stars!! This was a BIG hit at Thanksgiving. It was super easy to make, and tasted delicious!!! I also liked the fact that I was able to prepare it in advance, and then pop it in the oven when I was ready. The last couple minutes, I put the broiler on low for that crispy cheese top. I did modify this recipe a little bit, though...I didn't have Parmesan and Romano cheese by themselves, so used the Italian Blend shredded cheese instead. I also used jarred minced garlic instead of a fresh clove, and didn't have any basil so did without. Thanks for posting this recipe!!!

I also used some healthier options, low fat cream cheese and low fat sour cream (used the sour cream as some other reviewers suggested) and a tablespoon of low fat mayo. Thanks for the great recipe!

city:

country:
None
text:
very good!   i thought it was very yummy!  i was a little nervous, but it's a keeper.  i had doubled the recipe for a party & wanted to make it ahead, so i mixed together all of the ingredients minus the spinach & artichokes the day before.  i thawed the spinach in the microwave & places it in a small collander over a bowl uncovered in the fridge so it could continue to drain overnite & maybe dry out a little.  this worked very well!  it was still  pretty wet when i went to use it but it worked just fine. ( i also used as someone else suggested 1/2 sour cream & 1/2 mayo, no salt at all-replaces with a dash of garlic powder, added 1/2 cup moz. cheese into the mixture & another 1/2 on top and i only used 1 1/2 cans artichokes).  the day of the party all i had to do was fold in the spinach & artichokes & top with moz. & bake.  i baked it for 30-35 mins. since i had doubled the recipe, was perfect!  give it a try!  i served it w/tortilla scooping chips!

I have made this several times and it is asked for time and time again! Just a few changes as suggested by other people - Usually use whipped cream cheese; 1/8 cup mayo and 1/8 cup sour cream instead of all mayo; I always use creamed spinach instead of plain chopped; and I seem to end up adding more garlic (Love Garlic Garlic by Tastefully Simple!) :) I have made it in the crock pot, and baked - both are great!

text:
I followed some advice of others: used sour cream instead of mayo, added 1/8tsp cayenne, and mixed all the cheese together. I did use the basil plus 2 minced garlic cloves, and used about 1 cup fresh spinach chopped, a bar of the reduced fat cream cheese, and buttered the 8x8 glass baking dish before putting dip into it. I let the cream cheese come to room temp before mixing and it mixed just fine. Used 1/2 cup shredded Italian cheese instead of 1/4 cup parm. + 1/4 cup mozz. Lastly, I sprinkled a pinch or two of the Italian cheese on top before putting it in the oven. Pretty tasty! Definitely party worthy.

text:
This is my go-to recipe for parties and potlucks. Everyone loves it and it always disappears quickly. I have tried many spinach/artichoke recipes and I feel that this is the best. A couple recommendations--make sure you remember to defrost the spinach ahead of time. This makes it easier to drain and work with. I have also tried putting in some fresh chopped spinach, which gives an interesting texture. I also like cooking and serving it in a pyrex pie plate--it makes it just the right depth for scooping! yummy served with frito scoops or torn up pumpernickel bread.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Spinach Artichoke Dip has to be my favorite of the dips. I've been looking for a recipe that could become "my" recipe -- one that I would use again and again. In trying to do this, I've used several recipes on this site, and some that are not on this site, but I really do think that I've found it in this one, with some, minor changes to the recipe (thus giving it 4 stars instead of five).

I read through the comments and noticed that quite a few people used a quarter cup of sour cream instead of mayo in the recipe. I've made this twice -- once with full fat sour cream and once with Hellman's Light Mayonnaise and I honestly didn't taste a difference. I'll probably wind up using whatever I happen to have on hand in the mayo/sour cream department next time I make the recipe.

What I did do was I put an entire bag (4 cups?) of mozzarella in (primarly because I use a large baking dish for the recipe and it filled up better that way). 

The end result was delicious, and it was incredibly easy to make. I've also found that it reheats well.

text:
I am known as a ShortCutCook, and I ALWAYS substitute canned spinach for the fresh or frozen.  The recipe is very forgiving; you can use mayo or sour cream or half of both, dump cheeses in like crazy, and, if short, I also use jarred cheese sauces.  It just makes it creamier.  I also do a garlic overload.  This recipe is so easy and you can customize it continually.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this for years, always tweaking the recipe a little. I thought I would try this version (although I usually add some sour cream and thought it might not be as good without it) for Thanksgiving. 

Made it basically as listed (I am not a fan of measuring, so I just freehand) except I was too lazy to peel/chop the garlic and just used powder. 

I first mashed the can of artichokes in a bowl with the cream cheese and mayo. Then added the cheeses and seasonings (I did leave out the basil and added some "house seasoning" from The Columbia restaurant... our family lives near St. Augustine, FL and uses this seasoning in EVERYTHING) and then the drained spinach. 

Everything got stirred together and put into a mini crockpot. It stayed warm for several hours, and it was FANTASTIC. By far the best spin/art recipe I've ever made, and this will be my standard from now on. 

My mom LOVES this dip, and I had to sneak the leftovers back home (although she did ask me today where they were!!). When reviewing our "top three" dishes of the day last night, this one came up several times! 

Thanks Tiffany!!

FANTASTIC!! I just made this as a prelude to our Thanksgiving dinner. I didn't have garlic salt, so I used garlic powder and added a little more salt. I chopped the artichokes pretty fine (we have picky eaters and I wanted to "hide" the chokes so they would eat it). I used freshly shredded parmasan and ramano cheeses. I also added a little bit of grated parmasan on top. It turned out creamy and delicious! People gobbled it up and I was really proud of it. It's a certain keeper in my recipe box. THANKS!

text:
PHENOMINAL!!!  This is, by far, the best spin/artichoke dip I have ever tasted, and I get it at restaurants whenever I see it on the menu.  It is rich, creamy and very flavorful.  I was not stingy with the garlic, and added some fresh ground black pepper as well.  I also added about 1/4 cup of sour cream to make it super smooth and creamy.  At the last minute I threw in some of the shredded monteray jack cheese as well (I used that instead of mozzarella), and I think that helped to hold the dip together a little after it was heated.  I also threw in some diced red bell pepper for some color.  I heated it and served it in a large sour dough bread bowl.  It was a hit!!!  I will be making this recipe A LOT more often.  This one's a classic.

text:
I haven't ever had any use for artichokes ever before making this recipe so I am not an expert on them. 

This recipe come together very easily. It's essentially a casserole. Per a previous reviewer I mixed the mozzerella cheese in with everything else and was happy with the result. The taste was good but reminded me of greek food (something I'm not a big fan of). It had a brininess to it. Perhaps this was from the type of artichokes I used. They were Albertson's store brand in a glass jar and smelled strongly.  

My husband loved it though and insisted on taking the leftovers with him to work to share with his buddy. He didn't come home with any leftovers that day

text:
OMG..this stuff is awesome - I am literally munching on some I just made for the first time, on a Club Cracker as it's all I had available.  Tastes great on the cracker by the way.  I made this for my teenager who loves a similar recipe at a nearby restaurant.  This is as good or better if you ask me!  

I did a couple things different...as it was just my preference.  I mixed the mozz in with the entire mixture as someone said it's hard to eat with it all on top..(which I would agree), I also added double the amount of mozz as we love it..didn't come out as too cheezy.  I also omitted the garlic salt (thank goodness as I think it would have been too salty with the Parm/Romano cheeses (which are salty anyway).  Instead of the garlic salt as I love garlic, I added 2 gloves minced - perfect!  

Again..this is yum yum yum...I will be making it for my daughter's graduation party this summer...but in larger amounts!  Enjoy everyone!

None
text:
Very tasty dip.  I find it very hard to 'mix' softened cream cheese, so I put the cream cheese, mayo and an equal part sour cream in food processor to make it nice and creamy.  Then folded in the rest of ingredients.  Beacause a lot of previous reviews warned of the mozz on top becoming too hard as it cooled, I folded it into the dip.  Also, for color, I sprinkled paprika over top and for texture, sprinkled crushed butter crackers mixed with a little olive oil over top as well.  There wasn't a scoop to left!  All gone!  Presentation is best in a shallow baking dish, if you have one.

userID:
871600
Display Name:
Lori
isPro:

followersCount:
9

287

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've tried a few Spinach and Artichoke dips from this site and I've loved them all but this is BY FAR my favorite! Especially if you are looking for the restaurant dip recipe. It is just perfect and delicious! I used lite sour cream instead of mayo and it was PERFECT!! I used a box a spinach versus 1/2 cup and chopped again in my food processor with 2 cloves of garlic adding the cream cheese but I omitted the basil and garlic salt. I stirred in the shredded cheese, it is much better that way than on top! I thought it got gooey if you put it on top. A hard layer and impossible to dip in. I serve with tortilla chips . I mix it all together the day or two before and put it in a glass baking pan in the fridge and then when I'm ready to bake it I throw it in my toaster oven! If you want, add mozzarella and broil for a few minutes at the end. Definitely my favorite hot spinach dip.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW!!  Loved this recipe the first time and even MORE the second! Definitely use sour cream instead of mayo, mix in the mozzarella cheese instead of putting it on top, add a couple dashes if hot sauce (don't worry, it doesn't make it spicy), and microwave it for a 1.5 min BEFORE sticking it in the oven(for 10minutes) so the top doesn't get hard.  Tastes great if you garnish it with diced tomatoes!  I used a loaf of Italian bread for dipping.  Just make slices about 1/3in thick and throw it in the oven at the same time as the spin dip.  They take 10 min too AND are hard enough for dipping!

This is a hit every time!  Like some other reviewers, I use sour cream instead of mayonnaise, sometimes leave out the basil, and I stir the mozzarella into the mixture before baking, rather than putting it on top. Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2014-10-30T10:45:50.267
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
8803863
Display Name:
Danielle Heiderich
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
117
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5366781.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a decent starting point but needs work. First, ditch the basil, it just tastes odd. You can use a decent Italian seasoning blend but go lightly, or just use marinated artichoke hearts and drain really well. Second, no garlic salt, just use fresh chopped garlic, and pump it up to about 3 cloves worth. Saute the garlic plus about 2Tbsp shallots in a good, dry white wine until very soft. Yes, it needs to be wine. The alcohol will burn off for the paranoid out there, but the flavor will remain.  Next, dump all the cheese except a sprinkling of the Parmesan into the pan with the shallots and garlic and let it all melt together (very low heat please) and combine. It is REALLY thick so I use both mayo AND sour cream to loosen it up. 1/4c each, add the green stuff next and stir to incorporate and THEN dump it into your baking dish. sprinkle with the little bit of Parmesan you kept back and bake till bubbly. If you're into that sort of thing you can add stuff to this base also. I like some sliced black olives sometimes, or a bit of diced roasted red pepper. I've even added lump crab meat and crawfish tails a few times. Granted, it's not really "spinach artichoke dip" if you do that, but it still tastes yummy!

country:
None
text:
Good stuff! Tweaked this recipe a bit. I only had a 7.5 jar of artichokes, & it seemed to do the trick. Omitted the mayo for sour cream. Bumped the garlic up to 2 cloves, & roasted them over the flame on my stove with the peelings. (removed them after) I used fresh spinach, & made it 3/4 of a cup. Cut stems off and sliced the spinach leaves into ribbon strips. Mozzarella got bumped up to 1/3rd of a cup, & most of the cheese was mixed in like others recommended. I saved a little bit for a loosely sprinkled layer to cover the top, but made sure there was spacing between the shreds of cheese. Chip accessible, yet covered. Served it with warmed in the oven tortilla rounds. It was only 3 of us, and we cleaned the bowl! :d...

city:

country:
None
text:
Best spinach and Artichoke dip recipe Ive found to date This is fairly easy. The hardest part is gathering all the ingredients .  Its  absoluely tworth the trouble for sure. Its so awesome even spinach haters love it, just tell them the green stuff is parsley  or something else, This is one of those, all to rare recipes that don't need to be  tweeked. If your making this for 4 or more people, you will wish you doubled the recipe. Don't serve it to hungry peeps just before dinner, they won't be able to stop eating it. I seve with either Ritz , HiHo, or Club House crackers.  But am sure it would be awesome even on tree bark!!!    
NOTE: Further down the recipe it talks about sour cream, Ive made this recipe several times, todayis the first time we are going to substitute half the mayo with sour cream. In the back of my mind I am thinking " don't mess with a good thing" My curiosity  always wins over my commonsense.  Also I have no fresh garlic, I'm substituting the one clove of fresh garlic with 1/4 tsp. Garlic powder, and the all the grated cheese called for with:  "Lacotelli grated cheese "( "pecorino romano"),  I add the mozzarella  during the last few minutes of baking. I will update if any of these changes,  change  the recipe's awesomeness.

Really good dip. I did as some of the other reviews suggested and used sour cream and omitted the mayo. I also used more spinach (3/4 cup) and less artichokes (6 ounce jar), and I'm glad I did or else there would have been too many artichokes for my liking. I also use more garlic (3 cloves)as some reviews suggest and the garlic flavor was too much. Next time I will stick to the 1 clove called for in the recipe.

text:
I made this for a work Christmas party and it was a HUGE hit!  I doubled the recipe due to the amount of people at the party and I also did some more tweaks.  I used 2 8oz containers of non dairy cream cheese (lactose intolerant), 1/4 cup mayo, 1/2 cup non dairy sour cream, 1 cup grated parmesan cheese, 4 large cloves garlic, no garlic salt, 1 full 10oz box frozen chopped spinach, and 1 full cup shredded mozzarella cheese.  I cooked it in my crockpot on high for 2 hours and kept on warm for the party.  It was gobbled up and raved over....the recipe was asked for by multiple people.  I will definitely make this one over and over!

text:
So I wanted to make spinach and artichoke alfredo but wanted something a bit creamier. What I ended up doing was getting four cheese ravioli (frozen) and boiled it until half done. Lightly sprayed a casserole dish, and put them in a single layer. Put the dip on top and baked it according to instructions... Rich as all get out but AMAZING! The whole family LOVED it! Definitely making it again!

easy and delicious! i used 1/2 c mayo, 1/2 c romano cheese, dash of garlic powder in place of garlic salt. i also used 8 oz of mozzarella and mixed some into the dip and sprinkled the rest over the top. i used a small square glass pan and it took about 40 mins for the cheese to brown on top. served with crackers. very tasty!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out really good for my first time making this kind of dip. I decided to substitute a Kraft Italian cheese blend (pizza mozzarella, parmesan, provolone and emmental) because the grocery store did not have romano...it worked out very well. I also took other reviewers advice to chop the artichokes very small so they didn't stand  out too much, and also substituted sour cream for mayo. I also wouldn't top the dip with cheese before baking since it does create a hard annoying surface to dip through. Used melba toast, triscuit, and multi-grain Breton rounds (my favorite) for crackers. Would definitely make again!

text:
I haven't met a single person who hasn't LOVED this. I bring it to nearly every get-together because it's so yummy, cheap and easy to make! People always ask for the recipe, and often can't believe that something they "hate" is in there (mayo, artichoke, spinach etc.) Once I found this recipe I couldn't bring myself to order this at a restaurant - why do so when I can make a MUCH yummier, and much cheaper version at home? I would recommend doubling the recipe - believe me, it goes fast! Serve with anything from fancy crackers, pita or tortilla chips, or veggies (carrots, celery etc).

Mmm Mmm Mmmmm, this was delicious. I subbed sour cream for the mayo since I don't like the mayo taste and tossed some shredded Italian blend cheese in with the mix. userID:

Display Name:
JoeRik
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/131.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was skeptical because I have made other spinach dips that I thought would be great and were total flops, I thought this recipe would go that way too.  I was wrong.  This recipe looked and tasted restaurant quality.  I served it with baguette bread and it was delicious.  The only changed I made, because of how expensive romano cheese is, is I used a ramano/parmesan blend out of a shaker and did a 1/2 cup of it as opposed to a 1/4 cup of each of them.  Also I followed other recommendations and just added the mozzarella right in with it before it cooked.  Because I used cheese out of a shaker, it didn't all combine into a very spreadable dip, it was a little clumpy, but it was so delicious nobody cared.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1659500.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing!  This is better than any artichoke dip I've had in a restaurant.  Perfect with some toasted sourdough drizzled with olive oil.  I made a few changes and followed other's recommendations.  I skipped the mayo and used sour cream, upped the cheese to about 1/3 cup.  I didn't have any romano so I substituted more parmesan.  I didn't have any mozzarella but had a delicious Spanish cow's milk chees which worked wonderfully.  I mixed in all the cheese rather than a layer on top.  Also, I used 5 oz. of fresh, wilted spinach drained, much better than frozen. We are garlic lovers, so I used 3 cloves of garlic. If your guests don't love garlic, I would stick to the recommended amount or perhaps 2 cloves.  My husband loved this dip! I think it would be great with a bit of hot peppers as well to kick it up a notch!

Makes the chopping much easier.  I used 1 heaping cup frozen spinach and it reduced to exactly 1/2 cup.

text:
This was delicious! As someone else suggested, I mixed the mozzarella into the dip rather than melting on top so that it was easier to dip. I also had to add a little extra mayo because I neglected to compensate for the saltiness of the paremesan and romano cheeses, and it needed a little more bulk to make it less salty. It ended up being perfect!

text:
This was very good (one of the best I have had).  I doubled the parmesan since I didn't have Romano.  I also added about 1/2 cup of mozzarella to the dip mixture itself with the other cheeses and topped with the 1/4 cup mozzarella.  Mine was not dry, it turned out creamy.  I think the quality of ingredients do make a difference so use premium artichokes and cheeses. I would recommend using as mall clove of garlic, I used a large clove and it was garlicky.

text:
This is a great recipe, hands down one of the best Spinach Artichoke dips I ever ate. I made some adjustments along the way: I used mayo and sour cream (about a cup and a quarter of the combo...more mayo than sour cream), extra cheese within the recipe (I only added a little bit on top), I used a heavy hand when adding the garlic powder, and I only used a small amount of minced garlic. I used an entire 10oz frozen package of spinach.  I did not use any other spices, not even salt. It comes out creamy and delicious!

text:
this is my favorite recipe that i have cooked so far and everyone always tells me to make this for parties.  I use sour cream instead of mayo. I also use 1/3 less fat cream cheese and reduced fat sour cream and it really does not taste different than using full fat condiments.  I also up the garlic to about 2-3 cloves since I do not have garlic salt.  To replace the garlic salt I use either onion powder or onion salt and it adds amazing flavor to this dish.  I add a little bit more cheese  -hence the reduced fat cream cheese and sour cream :)  I agree with the other reviewers to mix the cheese in the mix but I also reserve a bit just to sprinkle on the top.  I love this dip with triscuts annd pita chips!

This was wonderful!!  I'm a big spinach artichoke dip fan but have never made it myself.  It was soo easy!  I did cheat and used an Italian blend cheese instead of buying all of the individual cheeses.  My only other change was to add most all of the spinach in the bag (I did not have an immediate use for it and did not want to waste it) and I added about a 1/2 cup more cheese.  I took others suggestions and mixed all of the cheese in vs putting some on top.  My fater-in-law bypassed the chips and was eating it with a fork.  He told me it was a great spinach casserole.  I'm keeping this one for life.

country:
None
text:
LOVED IT! LOVED IT! LOVED IT! If you are looking for a great artichoke and spinach dip then look no further.  I've tried other recipes but they were either too salty or were very bland. This one was absolutely fantastic and so easy to make. I only made two changes, similiar to what most others did that reviewed this recipe: 1) switched out the mayo for sour cream and 2) increased the amount of mozzerella cheese and used the majority of it to blend in with the rest of the dip and sprinkled a small amount to bake on top.  I made this for my New Year's Eve party and it was a hit.  To keep it hot and yummy and prevent the top from getting too hard, I simply used a plate warmer underneath and kept it covered with a lid - not that the lid stayed on it much since everyone couldn't stop eating it!  Another great recipe on this site that is worth sharing - thanks!

Served this at a New year's brunch.  It got rave reviews.  I doubled the recipe except used just one can of quartered artichoke hearts.  I used my hands to break up the hearts into smaller pieces instead of chopping them while they were draining in the colander.  I also used a full bag of mozzerella.  I put most of it in  the mix and just a little on top but I would definitely do the whole bag within the mix next time as I didn't like the hard layer on top.  Next time I might top with bread crumbs.

text:
This is a great dip and well liked by everyone.  I left out the basil and garlic salt. I also used all light ingredients...light cream cheee, light mayo, light sour cream (used 1/8 c. sour cream and 1/8 c. mayo), light cheese.  I too mixed the mozzarella cheese in with the dip and then also added a layer on top.  I recommend cooking for 25 minutes and then putting on broil for about 5 minutes.  Will definitely make again :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my "go-to" recipe for whenever I need something that I know is delicious!!!  It is very good, and is also very easy to make.  I have a couple of suggestions... First, make sure to thoroughly drain the artichokes and spinach.  I even take the spinach and squeeze it to wring it out.  This keeps the dip from being runny.  Also, I double the mozzarella cheese, and I add it in the dip rather than putting it on top.  If you put it on top, it has a tendency to dry quickly and create a thick coat.  It is much better to add it in the rest of the mixture.  This is all I would change - overall, it is great dip!

text:
Very good. I brought it to a dinner party and everyone loved it. For those that think it's missing something you might want to add an acid ingredient like a squeeze of lemon juice or, as another reviewer added, tabasco, as that has vinegar in it. I also mixed all the cheeses in before baking. Lastly, depending how much you drain (in my case squeeze) the liquid from the spinach, you may need to add some milk or other liquid to loosen the dip prior to baking. Enjoy!

country:
None
text:
Oooohh, this dip is so good!! I've made this a few times and each time, there are no leftovers! Try to make this dip as spanakopita by separating sheets of phyllo dough on a surface. Brush melted butter on the phyllo, add another phyllo sheet, butter and repeat for about 4 or 5 layers. Cut in strips, then squares, spoon this dip in the center. Fold over to make a little triangle, seal and bake on 350 until golden brown. Yumm!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this dip for the first time a few months ago. Since then, for every gathering we throw at our house (BBQ, cocktail hour, party, potluck), I have numerous requests to make it again! Its the first thing gone & I could almost get away with NOT washing the dish because its nearly wiped clean! I took some recommendations from some of the other reviews & made these changes: used sour cream instead of mayo, use 2 packages of cream cheese instead of just 1, added the mozzarella to the mixture instead of on top, use fresh garlic gloves AND minced garlic, add finely chopped sweet onions (about 1/3 cup), add a few shakes of hot sauce. It turns out BETTER everytime I make it I think. I've passed this recipe on to a few friends who had the same results as me. A++++++ recipe ;)

text:
I thought this was very easy to make and the ingredients were cheap.  I did not have Romano cheese so I used more parmesan.  I also made mine creamier with more cream cheese, sour cream, and mayo.  I mixed in my mozzarella instead of sprinkling it on top because I didn't want the hard top everyone was referring too.  I also let mine bake and extra ten minutes.  This was good.  Would make again and add more garlic and salt and maybe even some carmelized onions for more of a kick because of the additional use of the cream and cheeses.

country:
None
text:
Really good.  I read the reviews about it being thick, so I added 3 heaping spoonfuls of sour cream and it had a great consistancy for tortilla chips.  I also didn't have fresh garlic, so I omitted the garlic salt (added just a couple shakes of reg. salt) and 1/8 tsp of dried garlic = 1 clove.  We like garlic so I added 1/2 tsp total and it wasn't overpowering.  Also had no romano cheese, so added 1/2 cup parmesan & mixed in some mozzarella (some used to cover top). Brought it to a game night and it was DEVOURED...my boyfriend keeps talking about it.  It's similar to restaurant dip. It's a keeper! Thanks!

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe for the Ohio State/Michigan game where we had a big potluck. Everyone loved it!

I made it the night before in my crockpots inner pan and put that pan in the fridge overnight. The next morning I put it in my crockpot on keep warm for a few hours before the party. It worked perfectly! You have to be careful that your crockpot doesn't get too hot though because the edges did start to brown a little bit. Other than that - it was perfect!

I doubled the recipe and since I had about 3/4 cup of sour cream left over from my cheesy potatos that I made I went ahead and threw that in too. 

It was great, easy to make and I'm getting ready to make it again right now!

Display Name:
KIMBERLYP

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fantastic! I did make a few changes: I used one 10 oz block of frozen spinach and one 10 oz package of frozen creamed spinach, and added 1/4 cup of sour cream to the mayo and cheese. I also used a mix of Romano, Parm, and Asiago cheese, about a 1/2 cup. I used 3 cloves of minced garlic (this was pretty garlicky, which we like, but you might scale it back if you're not as big a fan), some cayenne pepper.Also, I used two 6 oz jars of marinated artichoke hearts, drained and chopped, and reserved about 2 tbsp of the liquid for this recipe.I originally planned to make the recipe that calls for alfredo sauce, but I didn't have any- so I added some nutmeg to this recipe, about 1/4 tsp, for the alfredo taste. This turned out so well I don't think I'll bother with it now! Delicious!

text:
I always double this recipe, and it's a huge hit.  I never use the mayo, I use sour cream instead.  We only ever have pecorino romano on hand so that's what we use.  I mix the mozzarella throughout instead of adding it to the top.  This is a great recipe to make the morning of and then pop it in the fridge until you need to bake it.  I stopped looking for artichoke dips after I found this one.

text:
I think that this dip was too rich for my taste.  For those of you that do not enjoy the taste of mayo, I would only use 1/2 a cup and I would use 1 whole cup of spinach to cut the richness.  However, if you are a big fan of the tast of mayo and cheese this is the dip for you.  Also, I would increase the time you heat this dip to 40 mins.

text:
This is the best artichoke  and spinach dip I have ever made. It is so rich and creamy. When I use this recipe for entertaining it is gone in no time. I did substitute a shredded italian cheese blend (asiago, romano, mozzarella) instead of just the mozz. and it made it even better. I use whole grain flour tortillas brushed with olive oil and garlic, sliced into triangles and baked- great with this dip.

userID:

Display Name:
CYNDIDH

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great. I thought it tasted much better than Applebee's, although I made a few revisions. Upon the advice of other reviewers, I exchanged the mayo for 1/2 cup of sour cream. I also used a whole box, 10 oz, of frozen spinach. I squeezed all of the water out of the spinach and chopped off the ends of the artichoke hearts. I squeezed the excess water out of them as well and then chopped them up into small pieces. When I was mixing things together, my cream cheese wasn't completely room temperature. So, I added a few tablespoons of milk and that helped with the mixing. All in all, very, very tasty. Even my boyfriend, who hates spinach and artichoke dip, said it tasted good. He ate half a bowl full!

text:
Very good, even better than restaurant quality.  I also substituted sour cream for the mayo, and I suggest adding a 1/4 cup of milk to thin it out some. Also, stick to the recipe for the amount of cheese, spinach and artichokes. A quarter cup of mozz doesn't sound like much, but if you add more, it makes the dip too rich. I also stirred it in to the mix instead of sprinkling it on top. Very very good, definitely a keeper.

This dip was amazing!  After reading other reviewers' comments I substituted 1/4 c. sour cream for the mayo, and added extra garlic and a few dashes of crushed red pepper flakes. i made a few of the said changes and i wish that i had stuck with the original recipe.  i sub'ed the mayo with sour cream, and, fearing a dry dip, i didnt squeeze the spinach completely dry.  as a result, it turned out very loose, but with great flavor.  the next day, it was better "set" and it tasted divine.  add a healthy dose of cayenne and real garlic.

I use all parmesan instead of  half Romano, leave out the garlic salt and for some reason I made it 4 times using 1.5 cups of spinach before I realised I'd been misreading the amount however I'll probably keep making it that way.  As suggested by other reviewers I stir the mozzarella into the dip and, again, I read the amount wrong and added half a cup instead of one quarter.  If I don't have mayonnaise in the house I'll use sour cream with equally good results.  I mix this up several hours in advance and keep it in the fridge until guests arrive then pop it in the oven, which is convenient for me and allows the flavors to blend nicely.

There seemed to be something "missing," but when i heated the leftovers the next day, the flavor really came out; I guess it needed to sit for the flavors to meld.   Would defiantely make this again!

text:
I LOVE artichokes.  I love spinach.  I love garlic.  I love cheese.  I LOVE flavor.  Why didn't I ever make this before!?!?!  This is the best Spinach Artichoke dip I have ever had.  It beats every restaurant dish I've ever tried...hands down!  I did not have any Romano cheese on hand, so I subbed with mozzarella.  This was an excellent idea, because as I pulled my nacho out of the dip, beautiful cheese stretched from the chip to the plate.  It was fantastic!  Also, I broiled it for the last minute to give the top mozzarella a pretty golden brown color.  You can't beat this recipe!

text:
This is the first time I attempted to make a dip like this and it was very easy to make and didn't take much time at all.  

Everyone really enjoyed it and said how good it was.  I did alter the recipe slightly based on other suggestions.  I used 1/2 cup mayo (lowfat and no one noticed), I added more spinach, and I mixed the mozzerella in with everything else and only sprinkled a little on top.  Next time I won't sprinkle any mozzerella on top since it did get hard as others mentioned.  Also, I used marinated artichokes and minced garlic to be sure it was as tasty as possible.  

I plan to make this again soon and feel as though I have found "my dish" to take to parties.

text:
This recipe tasted almost exactly like some I had once at a Greek restaurant!  I did make a few money saving modifications.  First, I halfed the recipe since I was making it for the first time and there were only 4 of us to try it. Second,  since Romano cheese is not exactly cheap, I substituted Monterey Jack cheese instead.  And last I used minced garlic from a jar instead of fresh.  It turned out awesome!  Everyone really liked it.  I also used marinated artichoke hearts, which gave it extra flavor.  I can't wait to make it again.

I just threw in the whole package of frozen spinach and compensated by putting more mayo, parmsan cheese, romano cheese, and salt. I also used reduced fat cream cheese to cut down the calories. It was a hit, my friend kept the leftovers and heated it up in the microwave for breakfast! Thanks for the awesome recipe!

text:
This is a very good dip.  A suggestion though, regular Parmesan, and Romano both have a high sodium content.  Better to use Parmesan reggiano, much lower sodium.  I used Parmesan reggiano and left out the Romano .  Using both parm and Romano would be far too salty with artichoke hearts which are pretty high in sodium.

Turned out awesome. Doubled the cream cheese, sour cream (used instead of mayo), and cheeses. Bought quartered artichoke hearts and diced them for a smoother texture. Make sure that if you double the wet items that you also double the spices otherwise it can end up a little bland. Texture: 10:10, Flavor: 8:10 (just because I didn’t double the seasoning, so more on me then the recipe.)

I’ve made this recipe many times and it always turns out FANTASTIC.  I recommend following the recipe and don’t make any changes.  You’ll be pleased.  Just beware that this dip is addicting!  Me and the hubby had to use a lot of will power to not eat the whole thing in one sitting.

text:
GREAT recipe, though I did make some adjustments based on the comments, my preferences, and ingredients available in my house.  Recommend doubling it for a party and serving with baguette slices, pita chips, carrots and celery sticks.  It was enjoyed by all!  Will definitely make again. 
Here are the adjustments;
- Doubled the Parmesan and skipped the Romano (or could do vice versa)
- Instead of all mayo, did half mayo/half sour cream
- Dropped the basil entirely
- Added half a packet of Knorr dried leek soup
- Mixed in most of the mozzarella, leaving just a third of it sprinkled on top (commenters said if you put it all on top, it creates a crust that is hard to break through when dipping).
Notes: If you double the recipe, you'll use up one box of frozen spinach.  Diced water chestnuts might be another good addition to this recipe.
Review:
Rating:
4

text:
We loved this recipe! Instead of using this as a dip, we used it as an alfredo sauce. We put all of the ingredients into a sauce pan and cooked it on med/low heat stirring regularly. My boyfriend added a splash of moscato and it was a perfect addition! We added chopped grilled chicken and ate it on top of zoodles and it was INCREDIBLE! This is one of the best low carb dishes I've ever made. It can be difficult to have sauces stick to zoodles but this clung to every zoodle. 10/5 stars!

Maybe next time I will stick with the mayo to see if it will make it a little creamer than the sour cream.

I have made this so many times & have it bookmarked with ?? So I never lose it ! About 15 years ago I started really loving spinach dip from restaurants, so I set out to make my own . Cook book cooking is not my thing, I add what I have on hand!  I "m not a fan of frozen spinach so I used pre-washed spinach and cooked in butter along with crushed garlic. I would have added chopped onions if I had them. For the cheese I used Belgioioso Shaved Blend (Asiago, Parm, Romano. I made this for two different parties recently and it was very well received at both.  I used fresh spinach both times, but otherwise followed the recipe as written (except that I used 1/2 cup of a mixed Parmesan/Romano grated cheese). Sooo good! I made his for an appetizer on Christmas Day and everyone absolutely loved it! The only thing I changed was I used sour cream instead of mayo and mixed the mozzarella into the dip itself (the dish looks much more appetizing when you can see what it is rather than having it covered by cheese). I doubled the recipe and it fit perfectly into my 8x8 baking dish. You really can’t go wrong with this- it’s so easy and quick. Just make sure your cream cheese is very soft (room temp) or you’re gonna have a hard time with it.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dip was very tasty. I served it for a baby shower, and everyone loved it. I doubled the recipe, and there was none left. I used sour cream instead of the mayo just because that's our personal preference, and I left out the basil and put in two cloves of garlic. Also mixed in the mozzarella and then sprinkled a little on top. The best part is you can make it ahead and keep it in the refrigerator until it's time to bake it. Would definitely make this again for a party, would be great for watching football too. Super easy to put together which I really appreciate. I served it with tortilla chips, but it would be wonderful with pita chips or toasted sourdough or French bread too.

Made it exactly as the directions say except I used an Italian cheese blend in place of all the cheese. It was very good! Another reviewer suggested not sprinkling cheese on top, they said it became hard. I ended up doing as the directions said and did sprinkle on top and I am glad that I did. The cheese on top looked pretty and was soft and yum. I made it for a Halloween party and I am glad I jumped in line to get a little because it was the first thing gone. I served mine with sliced french bread and one loaf was the perfect amount of bread to go with it.

I took the advice of other reviews and substituted mayo with sour-cream, and then the first time I made this I was working on another recipe at the same time so I accidentally added about 1/2 tsp of Oregano to the dish and we loved it so much that we just made it a part of the recipe! I would recommend this to anyone!

city:

region:
