country:
None
text:
I had company and wanted to make an appetizer with things I had on hand..... So, I made this appetizer "pie" without the spinach. I also used only parmesan cheese. My ingredients were;  1 block of cream cheese, 1/3 c. mayo, 1/4 c. sour cream, garlic, 1 cup of parmesan cheese, (real, not the stuff in the green tube), a few drops of Tx Pete, and Panko crumbs on top. I baked it in a 350 oven 'til bubbly, about 35 min. It was devoured by all!!!

text:
Took advice from other reviews and substituted the mayo for sour cream and I'm not a fan of the mayo taste in dips either so it was a win-win substitution. I didn't have Romano so I doubled the parmesan. I then put it into my Little Dipper crockpot for an hour and it was perfect! We had leftovers the next day and it was even better so I think I would probably make it a day in advance to let the flavors really meld. The mozzarella really added that cheesey gooey feeling i love in spinach dip! Definitely get the marinated artichokes, adds so much flavor!!

text:
This recipe was SO easy, and SO good!  Made it for the first time last night, with only one substitution (I forgot the mozzarella cheese).  I put in queso freso (a Hispanic type of whole milk cheese) instead of the mozzarella.  Everything else was according to the recipe.

My friends gobbled it up, and said repeatedly how much they liked it!  I will definitely be making this again.  One note:  instead of serving traditional corn tortilla  chips, I will serve this next time with pita chips or something a bit sturdier/thicker.  The dip is heavy, and needs a heavy scooping type of chip.  

Make this--you won't be disappointed!

text:
This recipe reminds me of the spinach artichoke dip they make at a very nice steakhouse/restaurant here in town, it tastes exactly like it. I made it without basil and garlic salt, And left some chunks in bc that's how I like it. Mixed the shredded mozzarella, baked it, then added extra on top and let it get brown and bubbly on the broiler for 2 mins. I served it with light tortilla chips, sour cream and salsa (that's how the restaurant serves it here)- omg!
Delicious! My bf and family couldn't stop raving about it all night. Keeper. Thank you for the great recipe.

My family can't get enough of this dip (Actually I don't like to put it in the same category as dip because it's so much more than a simple dip).  Easy, quick, delicious; and because my family is often so impatient to wait until it is baked, I've also heated in the microwave with wonderful results.  (I did add about 1/4 cup of sour cream -- not sure it made a difference, but I had it on hand).

text:
I've made this a few times and it's always a hit.  I have made it exactly to recipe and it is great.  I have made it with various cheeses depending on what I have on hand, and it's still great.  I've used fresh spinach instead of frozen--amazing and my preferred options.  I have even added a little lemon zest which isn't super obvious but seems to liven up the flavors.  Basically, this is a great recipe to use as is or just as a base depending on what ingredients you have on hand.  It's great with both chips or your favorite bread side.

Tip: use the smallest artichokes you can find or don't be afraid to cut up whatever you have.  When they are too big, it can be hard to easily get a scoop with your chip.  The smaller the artichoke, the easier for potluck sharing when you may not have individual spoons on hand to help you out.

I've made this dip at least 25 times if not more, and everyone always loves it.  People ask me to bring it to their parties all the time.  I always add more spinach because I rationalize that I'm getting my veggies in :)  The first time I made the recipe exactly as written and loved it. Give this a try, I haven't met anyone that didn't love it.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This dip is delicious! I took this to my moms for Sunday dinner and my family was raving about it. I followed the recipe mostly as written except I used marinated artichoke heart instead of can artichokes because that was all I had on hand.  I only used a 6oz jar because I did not want them to over power the dip. Perfect flavor combinations! I drained the artichokes first then minced as small as I could before adding them to the dip. I also, added about a 1/4 cup of mozzarella to the dip, mixed everything together then baked it for 25 minutes, then I topped the dip with more mozzarella to cover the top and baked it until the cheese was melted & bubbly (about 10 more minutes). Definitely will be making this again. It was extremely quick to put together and delicious!

text:
First, I would like to say that I had given up on spinach artichoke dip recipes, because they would never turn out like the restaurant quality ones that we like.  A few years later, I decided to try again with this recipe and it didn't disappoint!  This recipe is delicious and so much better than any other recipe that I have tried in the past!  I did use sour cream in place of the mayo and used the marinated artichokes that come in a glass jar to improve flavor, which is maybe a couple oz's less than stated in the recipe.  My husband really liked it but wanted it to be a bit more creamy, which would be easy to tweak.  This had a great flavor and even though it may not be better than our favorite restaurant version, it came pretty darn close to it for an at home recipe.  Thank you for sharing your recipe and bringing the hope back that I can make a good restaurant quality spinach artichoke dip at home now!  UPDATE:  I made this again with a few tweaks.  To make it creamier, I added in an extra half  of a block of cream cheese, only used half the amount of artichokes, and did a 50/50 mixture of mayo and sour cream.  I also topped with swiss cheese along with the mozzarella.  THIS way came out absolutely perfect for us and is the combo I will use in the future.  Thank you again for the recipe!  It is the best spinach artichoke dip ever!!

text:
Very Good! Everyone loved this dip.  Mixed up everything together baked in oven for 15 minutes then put in crockpot on Low. Served with sliced thin french bread and tortilla chips.   As most others, I used sour cream instead of mayo and used whipped cream cheese.  Followed recipe except for items I didn't have:  For romano used mix of shredded parm and mozzarella to make up the 1/4 cup, 1 and 1/2 cups chopped fresh spinach (just chopped out of bag, stems and all), 1/8 teaspoon garlic powder instead of garlic salt, 1/8 teaspoon black pepper,  1/4 teaspoon salt.  Skipped the basil. Yum!!!

Tried out this recipe for the first time yesterday for our annual Christmas Eve dinner and it was a great hit! Everyone kept going for more! I took others advice and replaced the mayo for sour cream. I also only used spinach as I have never worked with artichokes before and was a little worried. Will definitely be making this again!

text:
I've made this recipe about a dozen times now and it has consistently delicious results! I took other reviewers suggestions and use sour cream instead of mayo. I also buy the pre-shredded "Italian blend" cheese instead of buying three different blocks. I always make a double or triple batch so I have to cook it much longer. For parties, I have made it in a small slow cooker, taken the ceramic insert out of the slowcooker and baked it in the oven, and then put the insert back into the slow cooker and set it to low and it has been fine sitting on the table for a few hours! It's always a hit and has become my "go to" appetizer!

text:
Wow, wow. Never going to buy again as I will make my own and you have cheeses and ingredients leftover (except cream cheese and the artichokes) to make more. Also for the Romano I bought a parmesan, Romano cheese blend in the aisle where you find the containers of parmesan cheese. The blend comes in the same type of container. I did what the others suggested and used the sour cream instead of mayo. This was sooooo good and yummy! Def now a family favorite. My fiancé and daughter wouldn't stop raving over it. Goes great on Ritz crackers and ate it while waiting on pizza to arrive. Would also go well with pita bread or even a homemade pizza.

userID:
11365566
Display Name:
payapooch
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made it today, in fact, I'm eating it as I write this. It's creamy and hot, and I love it. I took some advice by other comments about using sour cream instead of mayo (no brainer from me because I hate mayonnaise). I also took advice on using more garlic, (someone said three cloves--I used two) and that was a mistake. Use only one!

I am an artichoke lover (I eat it alone with just melted butter), but I hate the canned artichokes that are marinated...It makes it taste weird. So I cooked three artichokes and cut up the hearts for this recipe. I love the taste when I bite into a peice of the heart in the dip, just delicious!

Oh, and I also would use less garlic salt. And don't go crazy with the regular salt with the dish. I couldn't find romano cheese, so I used more mozzarella (fresh and grated it myself). 

Enjoy this lovely dip!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-04-27T09:33:20.113
helpfulCount:

userID:

Display Name:
Momo-milk
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dip was excellent!  As other reviewers suggested I mixed the mozzarella in with everything else which was much better.  I doubled the recipe and baked it in a 8x8 glass dish.  Used part sour cream and part mayonnaise but I think next time I will just use mayonnaise as I could taste the sour cream a bit too much.  I love sour cream, just not in my spinach artichoke dip, I guess.  I also used jarred minced garlic and jarred marinated artichoke hearts for a bit more flavor.  Cut the artichoke hearts up even further with kitchen scissors to make them more dip friendly.  Baked at 375 instead of 350 for the same amount of time (it was pretty thick in the 8x8 pan).  Served it for lunch with tortilla chips and parmesan garlic herb pita chips--the flavor of the pita chips complimented the dip VERY well.  I will definitely make this again!

userID:
10518519
Display Name:
amanda_0320
isPro:
False

0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This turned out great, and was very easy! My only criticism would be that it is a little on the salty side (however, I am very sensitive to salt, unlike most people, so it could be that it is just me). Next time, I'll probably rinse the artichoke hearts first to eliminate some of the saltiness. I didn't add any table salt at all, and used a lot of black pepper because I love it. I also diced a roma tomato and mixed it in the dip, and as a garnish on top. I baked mine in a loaf pan, which was very easy and convenient to bring to the holiday party I was making it for. The 25 minutes was perfect. I couldn't find Ricotta cheese, so I just bought a Parmesan-Asiago blend, and used 1/2 c. total of that. I also just mixed the Mozz in with the dip, instead of as a garnish on top. Lastly, I garnished with more black pepper. I will definitely be using this recipe again!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
The only modification I make to this recipe is using fresh minced garlic (LOTS of it) and adding a dash or two of regular salt. I've also used a variety of cheeses, and while I usually stick to the recipe, if all you have is mozzarella, just use 3/4 cup of that and you'll still end up with a great dip. I always, always, ALWAYS serve with corn tortilla chips (for people with gluten allergies) as well as Dawn's pita chip recipe from this site.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an absolutely perfect base recipe to make any kind of artichoke dip! Last Thanksgiving, finding ourselves at a lack of spinach, my mom and I used napa cabbage instead--it turned out absolutely delicious! When using this recipe, I did the same (substitute cabbage for spinach) and used a little less cream cheese to take away some of the fat content. I also added red peppers & some hot sauce, as suggested by KittyFanatic. It was DELICIOUS! I had to cook it a little longer to get the moisture out--about 35 minutes instead of 25.
Because this was a gift for my mom, I threw in some finely chopped sundried tomatoes and dried cranberries because she loves both those, and the cranberries were sweet against the cheese. Good flavor combination. Awesome recipe to experiment with!

userID:
5034537
Display Name:
Sabrina Guidry
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2270704.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love it. With my own twist of course.  I doubled the recipe for a gathering. Therfore, all my suggestions apply to a doubled recipe.  I used 2 cups of tightly packed and well drained spinach. I  sub the mayo for sour cream as others did plus a few more dallops. For goat cheese lovers only, I added 4oz of "four peppers" goat cheese.  I used a total of 4 garlic cloves. Did not add extra salt. I also didn't add the artichoke because I forgot to buy it.  Following other suggestions, I added a dash of cayanne and a dash of nutmeg. I thought it still needed something so I added a dash of chicken boulion powder, lightly. I cooked mine in a slow cooker so I could adjust as needed.  I wound up having to add 1/2 cup of water. I guess I drained the spinach a little too well. Then, I took it to a friends house, topped it with bread crumbs and tomatoes and tossed in the oven for a few. I also served them with Pita Chips from this site. Perfection for me!

text:
Best spinach and artichoke dip I've ever had, and that includes those I've had in restaurants!  I took some others suggestions and substituted sour cream (actually low-fat) for the mayo and it still tasted wonderful and I'm sure saved many calories from the dish. The basil and garlic I think add the extra kick to this dip that most spinach/artichoke dishes are missing.  Will be making this again for sure.  Everyone really enjoyed it.

text:
I made this recipe for Thanksgiving last year and my boyfriend's Grandpa stood at the table and ate pretty much the entire batch.  I substituted plain fat free yogurt for the mayo and mixed the mozzarella cheese in with the rest of the ingredients.  I put it all in a small crock pot and let it cook until hot and bubbly.  I've baked it in the oven as well, but much prefer it in the crock pot because it stays nice and gooey the whole time.  I serve this with pretzel crisps instead of chips or crackers, I think it gives it a nice balance of flavor that way.  I have also used Wheat Thins and they are just as tasty.

text:
If there were 10 stars, I would give 11!  The dip was absolutely amazing.  I hadn't ever made a spinach artichoke dip before and I will never make a different one than this one.  Everything about it was perfect!  I doubled the recipe and used 1/4 cup mayo and a 1/4 cup sour cream, I used fresh chopped spinach instead of frozen, and used a 5 cheese mixture (provolone, mozzarella, romano, asiago, and parmesan).  Then for dipping I cut up a sour dough baguette and brushed it with garlic butter and toasted it in the oven.  Everyone loved it and most passed on the main course!  Thank you for a delicious recipe!

text:
OMG! BEST dip ever! Nobody in my family likes spinach or artichokes but we like spinach artichoke dip. I was never gutsy enough to try making my own until I was asked to bring this to a Bunco party. I hunted for what seemed like the most liked recipe and came across this one. I used sour cream instead of mayo since most of the reviewers did this as well, and I added 4 cloves instead of 1 of garlic. (we are extreme garlic lovers!) I also mixed the mozzarella cheese in with the rest of the ingredients. It came out SOOOO good! My 9 and 12 yr old would eat this all the time if I'd make it (and if it was healthier I would!) This dip tasted yummy with everything we dipped in there: veggies, tortilla chips, crackers, etc. I almost wish it wasn't so tasty because I couldn't stop nibbling before I even left the house. This was a definite winner and will be a regular appetizer at gatherings...or just for a treat!

text:
Great recipe! I mixed the mozzarella cheese in w/the rest of the ingredients since I didn't want to have to try breaking through the cheesy layer once it cooled.  Also, I used sour cream instead of mayo. Only thing I have to really comment on is I would have like it to be a bit thinner.  My chips kept breaking in the dip while I was trying to scoop it up.  Had to use a spoon. But that's more of a personal preference I guess. Next I'll use more sour cream or add the water the artichokes were packed in to loosen it up a bit.

text:
I took some of the suggestions of other reviewers: I substituted sour creme for the mayo, mixed in the mozerella and put extra parmesan and romano on top, and used about 3/4 cup of spinach rather than 1/2 cup.  I will definitely make this again, but I think in the future I will increase the spinach to 1 1/2 cup, because the cheese taste seems strong enough to handle it.

text:
This was pretty good.  It was easy to make, instead of chopping up the spinach and artichoke hearts, i put everything but the mozzarella in the food processor. I mixed the mozzarella into the mix instead of putting it on top, it would probably have been too hard to get dip out of if it had a crusty layer of cheese on top.  My only complaint is that the dip is super thick, a little too thick.  That may be because I mixed the cheese into it, though.  But it tastes really good.  I think the next time, I will add something to thin it out because I liked the cheese mixed in.

This reciped is awesome! I got sooo many compliments on the spinach dip when I took it to a friend's party on Friday. I didn't use artichokes, only spinach though. I used about 3/4 of a frozen bag of spinach (I believe 12 oz bag), and I should have probably only used half the bag. I will definetly be making this again especially because my bf was so amazed that "I can cook". Everyone I know loves Jay Alexander's con queso spinach dip and this comes very very close to it!!

text:
My husband and I ADORE this dip.  I've served it three times to different groups of people and everyone always loves it.  I personally think adding the garlic salt on top of the fresh garlic is a bit much so I omit that part.  The first time I made it, I just used extra garlic but I thought that made the whole thing taste like garlic only (which some people love but not me).  I like some mozzarella mixed in the dip and some melted on top.  I also substitute sour cream for the mayo and add quite a bit of milk (about 3/4 cup) to thin it out a bit.  Because of all the modifications I make, I give the original 4 stars but it is a great recipe.

text:
It is a great recipe however is a bit salty.  Parmesan and Romano cheese are salty enough for the recipe. If you like garlic, add another 1/2 clove of it instead of garlic salt.  I also recommend  1/2 the amount of mayo the recipe calls for.  It is an overall a great tasting spread rather than a dip.  I served it with butter crackers (keep in mind that crackers usually have salt on them).  It is creamy and has an over-powering spinach flavor. Thanks for the recipe.

text:
Fabulous! Every time my friends come over to my house for movies, etc, the first thing they do is look for this.  I use real garlic and sour cream by preference, but I've made it according the recipe and it's out of this world. I also bought one of those 'Italian' cheese packages to make it easier. For those who've wondered: you can't make a low-fat version of this.  It was dreadful.  I used fat-free cream cheese, canola mayo, and a few tablespoons of sour cream.  It didn't turn out at all.  I just went running the next time I wanted this dip instead of wasting money.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was a big hit! I also made some changes and took it to a family gathering and everyone loved it :) I used the following ingredients: (1) 8oz package cream cheese, (1/4) cup mayo, (1/2) cup sour cream, (1) 2 cup bag italian 5-cheese blend (2) cloves minced garlic, (1) tsp italian seasoning, (1/4) tsp garlic salt, salt and pepper to taste, (1) 14oz can artichokes, (1) 1lb bag frozen spinach. I mixed the cream cheese, sour cream, mayo, cheeses, and salts/spices until smooth, then i added the chopped spinach and artichokes. I then cooked it on high in my crock pot for 1.5 hours. I added more creams and cheese than the recipe called for but it made it very creamy and smooth and less chunky. I also added more garlic and spinach than called for. It was yummy and the crock pot kept the dip warm all night. There was none left!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/131.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome dip!  Everyone loved it!  I grated my own fresh Romano and Parmesan cheese and it really made for a tasty dip.  I also finely chopped the artichoke hearts and increased the spinach to 1 cup because it seemed like there was way too much artichoke bits and not enough spinach.  This worked out perfectly!  Other than those slight adjustments, I made the recipe as shown. 

You can definitely make this dip ahead of time and heat it up when ready.  I decided to separate the mixture into two smaller oven-safe glass dishes so that I could serve it on two different occasions.  I stored one in the fridge, covered in plastic wrap and without the mozzarella, so it wouldn’t dry out overnight.  The next day, I put on the mozzarella and heated it up for my guests and it was just as good as the one I served the first night!  Very easy and super tasty!!

text:
This is one of the best A&S dip recipes I have found. I didn't have romano cheese in the house so I used the parmesan and mozzarella in the dip. I also did away with basil and instead of the garlic salt, I just used more fresh garlic. 
I read the other reviews and did as many suggested; using sour cream instead of the mayo. I recommend the sour cream also.
I added a small amount of mozzarella on top before baking and it got nice and brown and bubbly, not hard and crusty as someone mentioned. 
I served mine with pita chips, fresh veggies and thinly sliced crusty french bread ~ I like to give guests options! It was so good, you could have eaten it with a spoon!

Made this for my husband for New Year's Eve.  Needless to say he practically fought me for each bite, and he doesn't even really like artichokes.  I decided to split the difference and used 2 TB light mayo plus light sour cream to make 1/4 cup, and kept to the original recipe by adding good quality finely shredded mozzarella on top.  I did not end up with a hard crusty top as another reviewer mentioned.  Top was perfectly done.  I do agree with the reviewer who said to chop the spinach and artichoke very finely.  This dip was delicious, and we served it with sun-dried tomato Triscuits.  I have already emailed family and friends this recipe, as it is a keeper.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I doubled this recipe because I was making it for a large gathering. My husband does not like a lot of garlic, so I added 1/2 tsp. of regular salt rather than garlic salt;  I did include  one clove of garlic minced as called for in the recipe.  I think the dip was a little too salty -- the parmesan and romano cheese are salty enough without any additional salt being added.  I will try this again without the garlic without additional salt.

text:
This recipe is fantastic!  I used it as a guideline because I wanted more than the recipe made.  I used two packages of frozen spinach, 1/3 cup of light mayo, 1/3 cup of sour cream, doubled the parmesean/romano, used three cloves of garlic, and subbed pepper jack for the mozzarella.  It was wonderful!  It tasted great as a cold dip as well.

text:
WOW! This is a delicious dip.
As good as Fridays or Olive Garden. I wanted to test the recipe before taking it to a Super Bowl party. I don't think I'll be taking home leftovers.

It's very creamy right out of the oven but does dry out a bit as it cools. I followed the recipe as is except used sour cream instead of mayo. I think I'll try some heavy cream next time and maybe one more clove of garlic.

Was equally tasty on toasted bread rounds and tortilla chips.

This one is definitly a keeper.

text:
Excellent!  It was a huge hit at the party we attended.  My preschooler and toddler were devouring it just like everyone else.  I didn't have any Romano cheese, so I just doubled up on the Parmesan.  I would have loved to use fresh-grated, but I couldn't justify the expense at this time, so I used Kraft shredded (not the powdery kind) and it actually turned out great.  I'm sure it would be out of this world with the freshly grated Parmesan and Romano.

I also had a hankering to put some Tabasco in it, but we didn't have any.  Someone told me they loved how spicy it was, but I didn't think it was spicy at all!  (I guess she was tasting the garlic??)

Thanks for this great recipe!

text:
Extremely good! My picky 17 year old son (who doesn't like anything green) really liked it! I was surprised! Made it for a birthday party and the family loved it.  Added about 1/4 cup half-&-half to cut back on dryness and it worked well. Also bought the Italien Cheese blend and used a little more cheese than the recipe called for cuz we love cheese! Also topped with a diced roma tomato. Served with torilla chips. Next time I make it I'll probably also serve with dark pumpernickel bread cubes and celery. Scrumptious and tastes like a restaurant appetizer!
